column3: classically known in English as Elsinore
column4: is a city in eastern Denmark. Helsingør Municipality had a population of 62
column5: 686 on 1 January 2018. Helsingør and Helsingborg in Sweden together form the northern reaches of the Øresund Region
column6: centered on Copenhagen and Malmö. The HH Ferry route connects Helsingør with Helsingborg

column1: It is known for its castle Kronborg
column2: which William Shakespeare presumably had in mind for his famous play Hamlet.

column1: The name Helsingør is derived from the word hals meaning "neck" or "narrow strait"
column2: referring to the narrowest point of the

column1: Øresund (Øre Sound) between what is now Helsingør and Helsingborg

The people were mentioned as Helsinger (which may mean "the people of the strait") for the first time in King Valdemar the Victorious's Liber Census Daniæ from 1231 (not to be confused with the Helsings of Hälsingland in Sweden).
Placenames show that the Helsinger may have had their main fort at Helsingborg and a fortified landing place at Helsingør
column2: to control the ferry route across the strait.

column1: Helsingør as it is known today was founded in the 1420s by the Danish king Eric of Pomerania. He established the Sound Dues in 1429
column2: meaning all foreign ships passing through the strait had to pay a toll
column3: which constituted up to two-thirds of Denmark's state income. With this income Eric of Pomerania built the castle Krogen. The castle was expanded in the 1580s and renamed Kronborg.  All ships had to stop in Helsingør to get their cargo taxed and pay a toll to the Danish Crown
column4: but it also generated a significant trade for the town. In 1672 Helsingør had grown into the third biggest town in Denmark.Johan Isaksson Pontanus (Rerum Danicarum Historica
column5: 1631) attributes a long and partially fictitious history to Helsingør.

column1: The Sound Dues were abolished in 1857 with the Copenhagen Convention
column2: where all naval nations agreed to pay a one-time fee.

column1: The oldest known fortified building of Helsingør is Flynderborg
column2: an early medieval fortress situated on a hill just south of the medieval city.

column3: Saint Olaf's Church

column1: A number of convents once surrounded the church
column2: but now all that remains is the church building
column3: today the cathedral of the Diocese of Helsingør. The oldest parts of the cathedral of Helsingør date back to the 13th century and tell us that the fishing village
column5: had grown to a town of importance.

column2: Helsingør was among the most important transport points for the rescue of Denmark's Jewish population during the Holocaust. Adolf Hitler had ordered that all Danish Jews were to be arrested and deported to the concentration camps on Rosh HaShanah
column3: the Jewish New Year which fell on 2 October 1943. When Georg Ferdinand Duckwitz
column4: a diplomatic attaché of Nazi Germany to Denmark
column5: received word of the order on 28 September 1943
column6: he shared it with political and Jewish community leaders. Using the name Elsinore Sewing Club (Danish: Helsingør Syklub) as a cover for messages
column7: the Danish population formed an underground railroad of sorts
column8: moving Jews away from the closely watched Copenhagen docks to spots further away
column10: just two miles across the Øresund from Helsingborg in neutral Sweden. Hundreds of civilians hid their fellow Danish citizens—Jews—in their houses
column11: farm lofts and churches until they could board them onto Danish fishing boats
column12: personal pleasure boats and ferry boats. Over the course of three nights
column14: 200 Jews and 680 non-Jews (gentile family members of Jews or political activists) across the Øresund
column15: to safety in Helsingborg and Malmö in Sweden.

column1: The car ferry line between Helsingør and Helsingborg
column3: Sweden is the busiest in the world with more than 70 departures in each direction every day. The route is known as the HH Ferry route and has been sailed by several shipping lines throughout history. The car ferry terminal is connected to the town's main railway station. From the station
column4: trains depart to Copenhagen every 20 minutes. Trains also depart to Hillerød and Gilleleje. There are another six stations or train stops within the city and connected suburbs. Apart from Helsingør Station and Ferry Terminal also Snekkersten station
column6: Mordrup station and the train stops at the line to Gilleleje

column1: The E47 motorway towards Copenhagen begins just outside the city limits. The town and surrounding areas also have a network of local and regional buses.
For a century the Helsingør Værft or Elsinore shipyard was a prominent landmark
column2: which covered the whole area between the town and Kronborg Castle. It was founded in 1882. At its height in 1957
column3: it had 3
column4: 600 employees. The last ship left the shipyard in 1983 and it closed the same year following substantial losses.

column3: was the second brewery in Denmark to ship bottled beer
column4: just three years after Carlsberg. The last beer was brewed at Wiibroe in Helsingør in 1998. Carlsberg continues to brew beer under the Wiibroe Årgangsøl label.

column1: After the end of the industrial era
column2: the town of Helsingør had to redefine itself
column3: and came up with an ambitious project: Kulturhavn Kronborg
column4: literally "Culture-harbour of Kronborg". It officially opened on 26 May 2013
column5: intended to appeal to tourists with an interest in culture. The main attraction of Kulturhavn Kronborg is Kronborg Castle
column6: a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Besides the historical attractions of the site
column7: William Shakespeare's play Hamlet has been performed annually in its courtyard since 1937. There is a longstanding tradition of performing the play in English
column8: and notable actors in the title role have included Laurence Olivier
column12: and in 2009 Jude Law. At the heart of Kulturhavn Kronborg lies kulturværftet or The Culture Yard
column13: a new cultural centre and a public library located in the old dockyard. It opened in 2010. The former dry dock now houses the Danish Maritime Museum.

column1: In the centre of the harbour basin stands the polished steel sculpture Han (He) by artist duo Elmgreen and Dragset
column2: commissioned by the City of Helsingør in 2012. It was inaugurated by then Minister of culture
column3: Uffe Elbæk
column4: in June 2012. It is seen as the counterpart (and even little brother) to Edvard Eriksen's world-famous The Little Mermaid statue in Copenhagen
column5: and has caused both praise and protests among locals.

column1: The Swedish city of Helsingborg lies a short distance across the Øresund from Helsingør
column2: approximately 4 km (2 mi). European route E55 joins the two cities; ferries connect the two sides.

column1: The new Danish Maritime Museum was designed by Danish prize-winning architects Bjarke Ingels Group (BIG).

Jørn Utzon lived in Helsingør in his youth because his father was an engineer at Helsingør Værft. Utzon designed The Kingo Houses (1956–60) and The Hammershøj Care Centre (1962) in the city. The project was completed by Birger Schmidt (1966) after Utzon moved to Sydney to work on the Sydney Opera House.
